conversation.content: [quietly] You said my compound would help people, Rebecca, that we'd take our time with the trials and make sure everything was perfect before launch.
I know what I said, but the board wanted results by Q3, and your initial data looked so promising that pushing ahead seemed like the right call.
[voice getting smaller] Three people died because we didn't run the interaction tests with common blood pressure medications, tests I begged you to let me complete. [swallows hard]
Every pharmaceutical has risks, and we followed FDA guidelines to the letter—those interactions were statistically improbable based on your preliminary models, remember?
[almost whispered] Improbable.
Look, I understand you're upset, but dwelling on what happened six months ago won't bring those people back or change the fact that the drug helped thousands of others.
I keep their names on a Post-it note above my bench—Margaret Chen, Robert Torres, Jamal Washington—and every morning I think about the two weeks we could have used. [voice cracking]
[defensive] You think I don't remember them? I testified at the hearings, faced their families, took responsibility while you hid in your lab refusing to answer anyone's calls.
[barely audible] Because I knew what we'd done the moment I saw the first adverse event report, knew we'd chosen speed over safety like every cautionary tale I studied in grad school.
We made a business decision based on the data available at the time, and yes, it went wrong, but that's the nature of innovation—sometimes you fail. [sighs heavily]
Fail? [quieter still] We didn't fail a test or miss a deadline, we put poison in medicine bottles because quarterly earnings mattered more than my concerns.
That's not fair and you know it—I fought for your project when everyone else wanted to kill it after the mouse studies showed irregularities.
[fading] Maybe you should have let them.
So what, you're just going to keep shrinking into yourself, becoming this ghost haunting the lab at 2 AM running the same analyses over and over? [frustrated exhale]
I run them because I keep finding things we missed, little signals in the data that should have warned us if we'd just looked closer, taken more time. [voice breaking]

[softer] The review board cleared us both, said our protocols were standard for accelerated approval pathways, that no one could have predicted those specific drug interactions without extensive testing.
[almost inaudible] But I could have predicted them if you'd given me two more weeks, and now I can't even look at my own research without seeing their faces.
You want to know what I see when I look back? A brilliant scientist who created something that's helped twelve thousand people manage chronic pain, even if we lost three along the way.
[whispered] Those three had names.
[quietly resigned] I know their names, David. I wake up at 3 AM reciting them like some kind of penance, but we can't change what happened, only what comes next.

scenario: A lab assistant confronts the product manager who rushed their drug to market, resulting in three deaths from untested interactions.
